Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Distributed Detection Algorithms and Stochastic Modeling for Large Monitoring Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Operational and safety goals for the built environment demand robust, scalable and reliable large
scale monitoring for infrastructure systems. High performance real-time event detection and decision making
requires models and algorithms to process large amounts of data from dense sensor networks deployed
in these systems. Despite advances in the development of detection algorithms for such networks, there are
two widely recognized and conflicting obstacles: detection rules need to be sufficiently complex to adapt to
the spatiotemporal changes in the environment, requiring the sharing of data; but rules are constrained by
statistical performance guarantees and computation and communicational budgets imposed by the network.
This project addresses these challenges by developing a fundamentally new approach that jointly accounts
for statistical detection, communication constraints and distributed computation.
This research develops a framework that integrates the distributed computation and communication constraints
of the underlying network infrastructure with flexible stochastic modeling and learning algorithms
with spatiotemporal data. The modeling and algorithms enable simultaneous and sequential decision making
at many local sites, by borrowing information across the network in a statistically coherent and computationally
efficient manner. Combining the formalism of sequential change point detection, nonparametric and
probabilistic graphical models and spatiotemporal statistics, the project develops distributed and sequential
message-passing algorithms for detecting changes in the underlying distributions generating network data.
The models developed also offer new theoretical understanding of the trade-offs between statistical model
complexity, distributed computation efficiency, and structure of communication constraints within the network.

This interdisciplinary research brings together students and researchers from different areas, utilizing
and developing knowledge and cross-disciplinary skills in the fields of computer science, statistics, signal
processing and civil engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Restoring and improving urban infrastructure has been identified as one of the fourteen Grand Challenges in Engineering by the National Academy of Engineering. As existing infrastructure such as roadway, bridges, and buildings age, they become subject to significant deterioration. In addition, extreme events can cause further damage. Monitoring and assessing damage is critical for safety and reducing maintenance costs. The proliferation of sensors such as accelerometers, gyroscopes and cameras generates large amounts of data that can be utilized to detect, localize and categorize the intensity of damage or changes in various types of infrastructure, ranging from buildings to power networks. Yet, creating such solutions requires smart algorithms that can accumulate evidence collected over time and over multiple sensors and multiple sensing modalities and decide the occurrence of damage.

Existing health monitoring approaches have focused on detection of a single damage utilizing a small number of sensors and algorithms that need to be implemented in a centralized manner. In this project, we designed novel statistical models and algorithms for simultaneously detecting and localizing damage. In particular, we are able to detect when and localize where damage has occurred while classifying the severity. The algorithms can run in a centralized or distributed manner. The algorithms combine ideas from machine learning (e.g. graphical models), statistics (e.g. change point detection) and structural engineering (e.g. damage sensitive features). 

The methodology has been tested in a variety of applications utilizing real experimental data collected for this project in a variety of setting such as (i) steel-frame buildings subject to earthquake damage, (ii) bridge cable icing and (iii) power distribution lines subject to outages. The algorithms were implemented in a real sensor network system SnowFort built for infrastructure monitoring. The methods successfully detected damage with just a few samples of data. The methods have been made available in open source at snowfort.org. 

The project trained a postdoc and several graduate students in interdisciplinary research, data science, algorithms and experimental deployments. The algorithms from this project have led to collaborations in additional infrastructure problems such as detecting damage to flexible risers in the offshore oil and gas industry.
